content.webTitle: Bernie Sanders says marijuana sales should be regulated like alcohol

fields.headline: Bernie Sanders says marijuana sales should be regulated like alcohol
fields.bodyText: Bernie Sanders would remove marijuana from the most dangerous federal drug category if elected president, the Democratic candidate announced on Wednesday. The Vermont senator revealed his proposal during a student town hall meeting at George Mason University in Virginia. Sanders told the attendees that marijuana should be downgraded by being removed from the Drug Enforcement Agency’s Schedule I list of the most dangerous drugs. Sanders called it “absurd” that marijuana is considered in the same category as heroin. “In my view the time is long overdue for us to remove the federal prohibition on marijuana,” he said, lamenting that “lives have been destroyed” because of a criminal record over marijuana use. “In my view, states should have the right to regulate marijuana the same way that state and local laws now govern the sale of alcohol and tobacco,” he said. Last year Hillary Clinton, the Democratic frontrunner, said she wanted to “wait and see” how legalisation goes in Colorado and Washington before making a decision. However, she has also called marijuana a “gateway drug” and said more research is needed into its effects. In 2013 the Justice Department said it would not sue to prevent Colorado and Washington from legalising marijuana, although the department reserved the right to file a lawsuit against the states at a later date. Sanders’ proposal would allow states to regulate marijuana and would remove the threat of federal prosecution. The self-proclaimed Democratic socialist had suggested legalising drugs in the 1970s when he was running for office in Vermont, although he had been quieter on the subject since then. During this month’s Democratic debate Sanders had returned to his liberal position on drugs, however, saying that if he were a Nevada citizen he would vote for pro-marijuana legislation due to come up in the state in 2016. The anti-drug group Smart alternatives to marijuana has previously given Sanders a D-minus on marijuana policy. The Republican candidate Rand Paul, a libertarian who believes marijuana policy should be decided by states rather than the federal government, also received a D-minus. In 2013 a Gallup poll said 58% of Americans believed marijuana should be legalised. Other polls have suggested almost 80% of Americans oppose jail sentences for people caught with small amounts of the drug.
